title: Alfie Hewett Wins in Singles but Loses in Doubles at Australian Open
summary: Alfie Hewett is a British wheelchair tennis player who did very well at the Australian Open. He won his singles match against his friend and doubles partner Gordon Reid, which means he gets to play in the semi-finals. Hewett is trying to keep his singles title from last year. In the singles semi-finals, he will face Martin de la Puente from Spain. But in doubles, Hewett and Reid lost their match to players from Japan and Argentina, so they cannot win the doubles title this time. They had won many doubles titles before. Other players from Great Britain and Australia are also doing well in a different doubles event. The Australian Open is a big tennis tournament where players compete in singles and doubles matches.

background_read: The Australian Open is one of the four major tennis tournaments called Grand Slams, held every year in Melbourne, Australia. Wheelchair tennis is a Paralympic sport where athletes use wheelchairs to move around the court. Players compete in singles and doubles events, just like in regular tennis. Alfie Hewett is a famous British wheelchair tennis player who has won many titles. In this article, he is playing at the Australian Open, trying to win more matches and championships.
Article_Structure: WHO: Alfie Hewett, a British wheelchair tennis player, and other players like Gordon Reid, Martin de la Puente, Tokito Oda, and Gustavo Fernandez.
WHAT: Hewett won his singles match to reach the semi-finals but lost his doubles match with Reid, ending their chance for another doubles title.
WHERE: The matches took place at the Australian Open in Melbourne, Australia, on Margaret Court Arena.
WHY: The article reports on Hewett's progress in the tournament and the outcomes of his matches, showing both success and disappointment.

perspectives.description: Hewett might feel happy about winning in singles but sad about losing in doubles with his partner.
